newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Trade ties to top agenda of Kohl's Indonesia trip.
newsitem.headline: Trade ties to top agenda of Kohl's Indonesia trip.

text.p: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl is expected to concentrate on trade and economic relations during his official visit to Indonesia.
But German officials have indicated human rights and the thorny problem of East Timor could also come up in discussions on Monday with Indonesia's President Suharto and other government leaders.

Kohl, accompanied by three federal ministers and 56 German industrialists, arrived in Jakarta on Saturday and was due to spend a leisurely Sunday with Suharto among the Thousand Islands in the Java Sea north of Jakarta.

Accompanying them was Research and Technology Minister Jusuf Habibie, a close associate of Suharto who has retained close links with Germany, having studied there at the Technical University of Aachen.
Fritz Kleinsteuber, director of the Indonesian-German Economic Association in Jakarta, told Reuters there were good opportunities for German businesses in Indonesia.
Indonesia needs to develop small and medium-sized industries in layers below the established conglomerates, he said.
"We need to promote German companies moving into Asia. For me, China is number one in Asia. But China is not the place for medium- and small-sized industries.
"Indonesia is the place. There is no doubt they are coming," Kleinsteuber said.
Germany is Indonesia's largest European market. Two-way trade amounted to 6.8 billion marks ($4.46 billion) in 1995, 75 percent higher than five years before.
"We do not need to improve our relationship. Our relationship is excellent," Kleinsteuber said.
Kohl has called Suharto, who underwent medical checks near Frankfurt earlier this year, a "good friend of Germany".
But a German government official said last week Kohl would raise the issue of human rights during his visit.

Self-exiled East Timorese resistance leader Jose Ramos-Horta, who was awarded the 1996 Nobel Peace Prize jointly with East Timorese Catholic Bishop Carlos Belo, urged Kohl on Friday to press Suharto to begin withdrawing troops from East Timor.
Indonesian troops occupied the former Portuguese colony in 1975 and annexed it the following year, a move the United Nations has refused to recognise.
Portuguese Prime Minister Antonio Guterres has also appealed to Kohl to raise what Guterres called "intolerable conditions" in East Timor.
Ramos-Horta, who lives in Sydney, Australia, has said no country in Europe had more influence on Indonesia than Germany.

Suharto's official visit to Germany in 1995 was marked by demonstrations by human rights groups who accused Indonesia of sacrificing human rights and the environment for economic growth -- currently running at around eight percent per year.
Kleinsteuber said German public opinion toward Indonesia was positive but perceptions had changed since the Nobel Prize award.
But he added: "I am buoyant, of course, because I know Indonesia will be able to master the difficulty and trust will return."
Kleinsteuber said German business had missed the initial opportunity to take advantage of Asia's fast-growing economies.
"Somehow, they missed the first train, but they now are catching the next one," he said.
Kohl will leave for the Philippines on Tuesday morning and then go on to Japan.
